body:
It's not actually the initial scan - that does happen in the background.

It is however an initial database traversal to figure out what we have in the folder (supposedly, etc, since it's before the scan) so that we can answer questions about it relevantly in the API. We've discussed it back and forth a couple of times before, but the short of it is that if we don't do this you'll have a bunch of API methods that return 500 or bad data until this is done.

I think your log is cut off a bit early, but you'll see some "initial scan completed" log entries when that part is actually done. The "ready to synchronize" thing is just that we've created the structures and summarized what we have in the database.

Now... What takes time in that step is that we actually look through all database entries for the folder to make sure that they are not corrupt, and to count them. We could potentially keep the count in the database instead of doing it at startup, but then we need to account for the fact that it may be incorrect. Maybe recalculate it now and then.

Right, I wasn't sure what exactly is going on, I was only going by the log messages.

So if I understand you correctly, Syncthing needs to have this information while it's running. So it should be enough to store it in the database when Syncthing is stopped. Then you just need to handle the case where Syncthing crashes (you could probably do that by saving timestamps for last start/stop and comparing them.

It definitely seems worth the effort, considering how much time is spent on this calculation on every start.
this is not a bug. its normal behaviour.

issue.title: "need" list should be kept in database

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New features or improvements of some kind, as opposed to a problem (bug)

labels.name: frozen-due-to-age
labels.description: Issues closed and untouched for a long time, together with being locked for discussion

rename.from: Initial Folder Scan slows down Startup
rename.to: Keep enough counters and state in the database to avoid initial database traversal

body: I intend to fix this one.
Getting rid of initial scan seems like a hard problem, so I just hope this doesn't end up a 'I have a branch (TM)'.
Yeah it’s nontrivial but totally doable. Lets try to keep the snark to a minimum in the issue tracker though and I think we’ll all be happier.
This doesn't get rid of the scan though, just makes the ui available faster, right?
Or perhaps doesn't even do that, just avoids updating the database after the initial scan?

It avoids the *database* scan most of the time, so I think it does get rid of it for all practical purposes.

@Nutomic this is for you. test the shit out of it :D

Pretty cool, startup takes around 1 second on my tablet now.

However, it seems that sometimes (around every 5 starts), it still performs an initial scan of the folders. Maybe it has something to do with the fact that one of the folders is stuck "syncing" because of ignores, and because a file is too large for FAT32. Nothing unusual in the logs, even with STTRACE=all.
